posts.title: #GreatLent2014
posts.markdown:
So today is the end of the Great and Holy fast of 2014, or otherwise known as Easter. Had all types of emotion run through me today during and after church, wondering what to eat today rather than focus on the mental aspects of it. Seriously, I felt like dancing to all the hymns today at church (I was that excited). You don't know how I look forward to this day every year, besides Christmas of course. It's true what the infamous Tenny Thomas achen was saying about Easter being the "festival of festivals" and how we put on our BEST clothes, and yes I LITERALLY spent the day before, shopping for new clothing items and accessories. It's practically my second Christmas. 

But all in all, this lent has taught me a lot. I feel like every year it's the same for me in terms of having similar problems faced during lent. If you know me, some people describe me as the Incredible Hulk. I can struggle with anger, a lot. Especially with having temp jobs to looking for a full-time one, or even just applying to grad school programs in computer science. I am often angry because I want people to be satisfied with their needs first ahead than my own. When I went to my first confession back in 2011 at Baltimore Leadership Camp, Leeson achen made me realize that I strive for perfection a lot (as a typical Indian-malayalee would). I mean I know there's a whole bunch out there since the Internet is a HUGE place to go to for tutorials and such on anger management. But in my mind, being the Internet the way it is with advertising, I think that there's no way to really control it. I guess since then, or at least since college started, I have been often quiet a lot mainly because I will always try to hold it in from saying something lame. Then again, this lent has made me make confident decisions in wanting something urgently (of course not love yet). 

Happy Easter to all, and to all a good night.

posts.title: Who am I really?
posts.markdown:
So, I forgot to post this yesterday but here goes. 

I actually didn't have a bad weekend at all. A couple of cousins from Philly came on Saturday to spend lunch with us, while they were still here in New York. After that, was getting ready to head out to a future leadership camp committee interest meeting at 'cherry lane' church. On the way there, I was pretty darn excited, I got the radio pumped to a high enough volume, got a parking spot (not that it matters) and met some old and new friends. But then again, I get excited because I definitely want to be a part of this once-in-a-lifetime experience assisting with the technology aspect of things for the year to come. We've had the pleasure of having a former NYLC convener and a former committee member speak about their experience(s). After hearing, I didn't know if I wanted to sign-up or not. A while later, it was time to nominate people for convener(s) and lead(s) for the respective sub-committees. I mean I hear all sorts of names of those who were/are active and those who weren't. Out of nowhere, I hear a young gentleman say 'Chris', pointing at me apparently (I initially thought there was someone named Chris behind me, knowingly there wasn't). And another young gentleman seconded that. I could've sworn I had no intention on becoming convener nor lead, I just wanted to be a part of this just for the technology support. After hearing my name, I was thinking of what Moses said to God of who am I to lead these people? Like really? ME?! I wanted to decline at first because most people who were nominated did as well, but then again, I was talking to the person right next to me (who happens to go to my parish) and she said "let's see how it goes." So, I didn't resist raising my hand wanting to decline. After that, there were three remaining candidates, and each were given a short message on why they are good for the job of being convener (just to be clear: the result is not official until the diocesan metropolitan bishop says so). . As my turn came up, I said I involved myself in many activities within the national and area levels (i.e. website, leadership camps, missions trip, etc.). I mean I forgot some things out, but as they were tallying the results and said the other two won, I kind of felt a little overwhelmed because I thought I'd let those two people down for mentioning my name. While on the way back home, I was thinking over and over throughout the weekend, I was thinking what am I good for then? I mean do people care so much about a camp website, the logistics, and other important types of information?. I guess what I'm trying to say is that sure I felt a little sad, but then again satisfied at the same time for making some sort of influence unto others. I guess that's what truly matters in life, the little and ordinary things. 

As Thirumeni (bishop) and the diocesan team looks over all of the applications, please pray for them as they make a suitable decision in making a fantastic team to be a part of this truly life-changing experience. 

UPDATE: Well, by the Grace of God, I've made the New York Leadership Camp committee. Sadly, I'm not convener nor lead, but I have the greatest title of all: . Visit us on the web at [nylc2015.com](http://nylc2015.com/)

posts.title: #Feed50!
posts.markdown:
Today was an interesting day spent in the city. First, I woke up to the sound of my alarm at 6AM to snooze it and go back to sleep, until I hear the sound of my mom's voice waking me up at around 6:40AM (The Big Bang Theory's Howard Wolowitz's mom's voice). I then get ready and start heading out to pick up a girl from my church, (wait for it...she's younger) to then go on our way to another parish member's house for us to get a lift from him all the way to St. Mary's Jackson Heights church. On our way there, we made a pit stop at a local dunkin donuts and got breakfast, and then headed out to the church. When we arrive, we start chit-chatting with other fellow parish reps. Next, we went inside the sanctuary for morning prayers and a parish rep meeting about different matters and such (Oh by the way, did you know New York will be hosting another leadership camp in 2015?!...shhh, don't tell anyone yet!). We start heading into the basement of the church to start preparing lunch bags for "people who are homeless" as a #Feed500 support (I added #Feed50 as the title because we only prepared fifty) with peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, a snack and a water in them. 

We all finally start heading out to walk to the subway train station (7 train) all the way down to Times Square. When we arrive, I finally looked up and saw the 2014 lighted sign up on top (as seen on tv on new years day), and of course we bump into Mario along the way (he/she sounded just like him). Next, we all separated into designated groups and walk a lot farther to 46th street. My group, however, came across some interesting homeless people. Some of my group mates said I got a tad bit more excited than I usually am about spotting homeless people on the streets. Until we came across a guy named Dirk (later he said Derrick, identity theft crisis perhaps?) and started bashing up on politics and how this world is so messed up (of course he used words I will not use publicly on the web), but it got me wondering that he's like anyone else, being frustrated at the miseries of government, economy and such. Later he said he got accused at a local library for being a bad guy for something I wasn't too sure of. But he's certainly right, government is screwing us over. He said he was from the Russian Orthodox faith and an immigrant too. I was a bit surprised at the fact that he also quoted St. John Chrysostom. After we talked, I spent for a coffee to give to him because he wanted one so bad (he said he'll pay me back, one day). But then again, it suddenly hit me, as Bobby Varghese (area councilman) pointed out, these people are just like us, their behaviors, actions and deeds. The only thing is that they look funny. I remember talking to him within the group and a couple walked by and smirked (S.M.H. = Shakin' My Head.) After that, we got food off of the biryani cart, for the first time, that Bobby always craves for, which wasn't so bad. Finally, we headed back to the church and we were on our way home. Here are some pictures from today, by the way:![](http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-KHr2HWM8dEk/Uttbb0cKw8I/AAAAAAAACkw/UsZRNjjQBI0/s1600/IMAG0555.jpg) 
![](https://fbcdn-sphotos-g-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash3/1524603_10153733794045541_1897453530_n.jpg)

posts.title: Blog Redesign
posts.markdown:
Apparently, I have been delving more into front-end development and user experience design. Based on my previous contracting jobs, I have been playing around with the Internet more and more, especially with browser developer tools (i.e. Chrome and Firefox), and git. I was having trouble where to host my personal space on the web whether it be on Blogger, Github, Harp, etc. And I was trying a lot of different methods in which to make me a better developer.  
Like recently, I have been playing around with the Twitter Bootstrap 3 framework integration with Blogger based off of a bookmarked I saved in my account. I've searched and searched all throughout Google (for many days) for this solution. Over the past few months, I've realized that blogging is getting more common now more than ever whether it be through Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Medium, you get the deal, in which people can freely post content. Another alternative I turned to was messing around with the  and making boilerplate templates. Even last year, I installed nodejs and wrote my first "Hello World" program. What I definitely like the most is that majority of sites (or all) turn out to be static in the end until the user(s) uses the web application. It's like what the  says on their features page, "Static is the new dynamic". Furthermore, this whole site is using blogger code with twitter bootstrap framework embedded, plus used the same color scheme as the [Harp platform's features page](https://www.harp.io/features) 
I have been meaning to get back into my blogging grind. Feel free to also follow me on [twitter](http://twitter.com/cthomas1211)

It's like what the @HarpPlatform says on their features page, "Static is the new dynamic". I have been meaning to get back into my blogging grind. Feel free to also follow me on twitter.

posts.title: Thoughts on Election Day
posts.markdown:
It has certainly been a while since I left an imprint on this blog. Been meaning to know which direction to take, but knowing me there's no direction. 

Anyway, in regard to this whole election day, been thinking about who to vote for, especially in times like the economic crisis, healthcare issues, and all of that political "mumbo-jumbo". However, been wondering why the heck people, especially the young-ins, do support Barack Obama for President. I mean honestly, Why?!? Because he caught someone that we were tracking for since September 11th, or even reasons being that he's African-American. Let's not forget the fact that he publicly stated his support for the gay rights community. It just sickens me that politics is as usual, and people vote for him primarily because he's black, seriously?!? 

I was watching the season two premiere of the ABC sitcom: Last Man Standing (the show with Tim Allen), last week, and it talked about the political-economical facts that this nation is currently facing. I've actually  this out in which Tim Allen responds within the show: "Obama is looking out for working people. He's gotta look out for them 'cause they're nowhere to be found." which is amusing, yet very true. Plus, citing the fact that Obama caught Osama Bin Laden, in which he didn't but some navy seals did. If someone says that fact one more time, I swear I'm gonna pull the "But what about Bush?" comment, because to be fair, under Bush's leadership, we caught Saddam Hussein and built a homeland security system (Yes-sirree, he did do something effective throughout the nation in which he got re-elected for a second term!) 

You see (for those of you who are actually reading this), I'm for neither candidate, even back in high school, I was always in the middle of the political spectrum leading a little towards conservative beliefs. To be quite frank, I don't give a damn about politics, because it's all a popularity contest of who's better looking (that's why JFK got elected). In the end, your vote won't count, you know why? Because it is all up to the electoral college (primarily made up of Congressmen) who vote for the President (At least that's what I've learned in high school and college political science classes). And that's another thing, READ your Constitutional given rights, people! There is nowhere in it that says the President makes the laws, or has much power in that matter (besides vetoing power). But furthermore, all it really says is it's just a title he holds to represent the country. If you really want to blame someone on war, peace, or whatever-the-heck, try finding out who your local congressman is and reach out to him/her to get your voice across government. 

[tweeted](https://twitter.com/cthomas1211/status/264745369580236800)

posts.markdown:

posts.title: Another semester begins!
posts.markdown:
This past week was my first week of the semester, of my third year, at SUNY Old Westbury. I have some interesting classes with decent professors, such as Constitutional Law and Politics, Technical Communications, Discrete Math, and Data Structures and Algorithms. So, the first week turned out great, and considering that all my classes are in the evening now, from Monday through Thursday, and one on Saturdays as well. Anyway yesterday, went to dinner with my family cousins at this new place called "Famous Daves" in celebration of my sister's eighteenth birthday. And of course, went to church today and relaxed at home a bit. 

In any case, just felt like sharing something in regard to what I've learned something interesting in my constitutional law class in which my professor pointed it out to us regarding that there seems to be no explanation of what the judicial branch's power really is, being expressed in Article III of the Constitution, and it made me think that there's got to be somewhere in the Article that explains what the supreme court really does, as well in terms of power. Anyhow, I'm not going to delve into it, so I'll leave it at that for some people reading this to think about. 

In other news, there has been a video posted up on the youtube site which is hillarious and amusing, in which I first saw it at work about a month ago, and now the video has hit up to nearly three-million views, so go check it out entitled "[Huntsville Rapist Bed Intruder Song](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TrWu13Uh2Yw)

posts.title: Operation Missions Week
posts.markdown:
So I know I haven't posted anything in quite a while on this blog, but had a really interesting previous week down in Wichita, Kansas where I was working with six other people, including Mat achen, on a MGOCSM missions trip held annually. Besides the heat and humidity throughout the whole week, I guess what I can say regarding the whole trip was that it was truly a remarkable experience to go through, in which we all helped build and paint homes for _Habitat for Humanity_, spoke to some wonderful sisters at the convent where we stayed for the entire week, plus took a tour to see a future monastery in place and an Antiochan Orthodox church with such sacred icons of the Orthodox church. Generally overall, it was truly an amazing and blessed experience working to change the world by making "one Act of Random Kindness [ARK] at a time" (Quote from Morgan Freeman in _Evan Almighty_). 

After arriving back home in New York yesterday afternoon, was extremely exhausted throughout the rest of the weekend, and had a family barbeque at our home last night.

I am very much trilled about what this summer is going to bring for me and my family.

posts.title: The Wedding Weekend!
posts.markdown:
So starting on Friday evening, went to Queens to go meet up there to get ready for my cousin, Ranjit and Erica's wedding rehearsal dinner. When we got to church things went well smoothly, and after that went off to dinner and got a chance to converse with both families. 

Anyway, the following day which was the big wedding day for my cousin, went over to his house at like ten in the morning for getting ready, breakfast, some photo shoots, and prayer. Then, went inside the limo on the way to church and to the reception hall. But on the way to the reception, we made a pit stop for another photo shoot at a beautiful place, which happened to be private property, but then again managed to get through it. Both the wedding and reception were really wonderful and well-organized, especially the band that played all night. After the reception, which ended at like elevenish, went inside a bar until one (didn't know how I got in) and conversed with some really cool people of Ranjit and Erica. I later went back to my hotel room (shared with Justin and Alex) and slept at three or so, and woke up at about eight in the morning. That Sunday morning, went off to have brunch and started to check out of the hotel. 

After the marvelous wedding, my sister and I went with the Colorado family on the way home. Then made a pit-stop on the bridge (don't remember which one though) to help out an accident that just occurred in front of us. So, went home, got some rest, and went off to Syosset for Jabin's birthday party, which also turned out great as well as some people, including myself, were really tired from the wedding weekend. So overall, I have had an amazing and fun-filled weekend to remember with family and friends. Also, I have met some of the old school Iota Nu Delta brothers there at the wedding as well, which was pretty much to me a big honor to meet them.

On an additional note, I also watched the movie _300_ just recently tonight on tbs, which I think happened to give a deep philosophy on Greek culture.

posts.title: Week 9 Progress
posts.markdown:
I know I didn't update this blog in a month as I usually do, so figured I'd write about what happened these past few weeks, starting from where I left off which was week 3\. I've been meaning to create a twitter account (instead of blogging), but then again not really a mobile user. Anyway, I've actually been getting used to my new school, hanging out with friends, browsing through some random videos and reading some new blog and twitter-feeds, plus learning some new programming languages on the side via youtube. On another note, getting into lenten season mode nowadays while reading all the Scripture readings, online devotionals, and special prayers. 

This past weekend, went to Philly with family and aunt from India to go visit some family there. For my first time in Philly, went to go see a movie with the cousins at the United Artist Theatres near their apartment, "Alice in Wonderland" starring Johnny Depp, which was an ok movie to watch. After the movie, went to Dunkin' Donuts, and spent the night. Then on Sunday, went to St. Gregorios, Philadelphia church to receive the Holy Qurbana for the fourth week in a row during GL (aka Great Lent). After that, went back to the apartments and spent some time there with the cousins until one cousin, Nathan, came around and things got really fun. So overall, the weekend was a blast there in Philly, wish I could go there like every month now.

posts.title: A Fresh New Start of the Year!
posts.markdown:
This past Friday, was the beginning of the new year of 2010, which my family and I saw the ball drop at midnight on tv. Then later that night, we actually had a get-together dinner at our house, which was fun indeed for me. The next day, Saturday, didn't do much until that night, went bowling with four of my other cousins. I actually placed first in the end of the game. 

Then on Sunday, went to church, and after church, went to the airport to pick up one of my aunts who flew in from Nashville. Also, got the chance to go over to my friend, Tom's house, in which I actually played, as a first-timer, water pong (the virgin-version of beer pong). After that, went to TGIFriday's restaurant with my family and aunt, and then went home. Overall, it started off as a great new year, especially spending time with family and friends.

posts.title: Week 12 and a Fun-Packed Weekend!
posts.markdown:
This past week I only had class on Monday. On Wednesday, went over to my former high school to pick up my diploma, nothing much has changed after I graduated. Then went off to Justin and Alex's house to help me with some homework before going on vacation on Thursday. On Thursday, actually packed up and went off to Philly for Thanksgiving dinner at Nathan's house. At the party, ate some delicious food there and then eventually played taboo because some people got bored. After that, slept over at Anita's house. 

On Friday, woke up early to go on a family reunion trip to Virginia. The adults were in the big van, while the kids were in the jeep. On the way there, stopped by the DC area to visit, yeah that's right!, the White House. Also, stopped by with lunch at this restaurant called Cracker Barrel. Then, it got dark, and all of our phones were out of range, when we finally reached there at the Eagle Landing cabins. Throughout the weekends, actually took the time to get to have fellowship and fun with everyone. We all did activities like playing games (e.g. Scattergories), canoeing, hiking, and zip-lining (although I didn't go). On Saturday night, our family had this talent show for some people perform, which was pretty hillarious especially the ones introducing the Molethu Family Enterprises. Then, on Sunday, packed up and was ready to hit the roads. Actually showed up at Philly around six and went home back to New York and reached at like eleven. I felt pretty tired from the long drives in and out of Virginia, but a blessed time with my huge Molethu family. 

Oh yeah also I think I actually won this week for my fantasy football league, even though I didn't pay attention.

posts.title: India Trip 2009
posts.markdown:
On Tuesday, August 4 went to JFK airport to head off to the motherland, aka Kerala, with the family via Kuwait Airways. Made pit stops along the way at London and Kuwait. Arrived there on Thursday morning, being picked up at the airport by my uncle, Sabuchayan. Got to see and hang out with my appachen and rest of the family for about three weeks. Toured around the many places of Kerala, including different homes, churches, restaurants, and of course the housing boat and Tamil-Nadu (southern tip of India). All of the homes now are kind of nice and comforting. Never forget some of the excellent and delicious food I've eaten. I've also learned a lot and gotten some great advice from my very wise appachen. 

Anyway, I felt kind of blessed being there knowing more about my family heritage and what not. Overall it was an amazing and blessed experience for me, and would want to go back again!

posts.title: Philadelphia part 2
posts.markdown:
This past three-day weekend I went to the Philadelphia MGOCSM _Hadootho_ summer camp 2009, which was absolutely an amazing and blessed experience down in Philly, considering the fact that I was the only one from New York. Also, I met some really cool roommates and friends. On Wednesday, headed down to Philly with my cousin, Anish, and on the way we stopped at JFK airport to pick up my aunt from Kerala. 

On Thursday, woke up extra early to head down to the campus to set things up and all. We did a couple of icebreaker activities and listened to a couple of devotionals and messages by the main speakers. That evening, had a barbeque, met some really cool and nice people there, and bouncing the volleyball high in the air. On Friday, did the usual on the listed routine, got the official camp t-shirts, and had a retreat-mode evening to night in preparation for Holy Qurbana. On Saturday, celebrated the Holy Qurbana at 9:00 AM, and cleaned everything up after people checked out. After the camp, made a pit-stop at Anita's house and then went straight to Jobin's apartment, talked, watched a movie for a bit, and slept early because I was tired. 

Today, went to service at St. Gregorios, Philadelphia and was a newcomer there as well. It was my first time seeing the church after the consecration, in which the church looked beautiful. Anyway, went back to the apartment, watched another movie (_Alvin and the Chipmunks_), and headed back to New York with the family. Also, made another pit-stop at Walgreens to prepare our trip to India this Tuesday, that should be fun then!

posts.title: Philadelphia part 1
posts.markdown:
This past Friday, I went to Philly with my dad in the afternoon to go see and move everything to my cousins' (from India) new apartment, located in 1865 Welsh Rd. While there, went to Wal-Mart to buy a bunch of material for their new home. After that, went to Jacob and Nathan's house to eat dinner. After dinner, went to Anita's house to sleep over. 

On Saturday, I spent the morning and afternoon home alone at Anita's house, while everyone else was shopping, which was pretty cool for me to explore their home. Anyway, we moved the furniture into their new homes, and ate chinese food for dinner. Later, Jacob and Nancy came along and got to hang out with me and the other cousins. Then, went to Anita's house again to sleep over. 

Yesterday, I did not happen to go to church, instead I went over to their apartments and we had an achen come over and prayed for their new homes. After that, ate pizza for lunch. After that, me and my dad went off back home in NY, which eventually led to traffic and a heavy storm. Overall, it was an amazing Philly weekend experience.

posts.title: Biblical Programming?
posts.markdown: Recently, I found this interesting [article](http://javascript.crockford.com/popular.html)
posts.html: Recently, I found this interesting article on a javascript guru's website, and as I was browsing through it, I found that there were even programming languages back in biblical times, stated in the book of Genesis 11:1-9. He explains that "...in which some excellent engineering talent was applied to the task of building a city and a tower with which to unify the world." Also, "Designers who makes their language too complex will confuse the language, sayeth the LORD."

posts.title: Great Day!
posts.markdown:
Today was actually a great and fantastic day because of several reasons. First, I received an A on an economics test, and participated in every class (including communication and political science). 

During the usual free hour period, went off to the CCF (Calvary Christian Fellowship) meeting where we ate, watched a video clip, and discussed about discipleship (notice I wrote about this on my blog earlier). 

Later, in my poli sci class, the professor discussed about Congress(one of my favorite topics in American Politics). A while later, the professor went off topic a bit discussing about America's national pastime, baseball, in which he was a big fan of the Yankees and talked about many different players' perspectives. Anyway, I've had a great day today, just wished everyday could be like this (LOL), not to mention that today's my mom's birthday!

posts.title: Triumphant Weekend!
posts.markdown:
This past Friday at 3PM, I finally passed my road test, in Wantagh, with zero points off. I was amazingly shocked at the fact that I had a perfect score because I thought I messed up, but I didn't. Later on, went off to dinner with the family at _Friendly's_. 

Anyway, yesterday, I went to the mall at night, dropped off by my parents, to spend some time alone shopping. I shopped at _Hollister_ and _American Eagle_, and purchased some decent clothes. Then, had dinner at home, with family, which was brought from Wendy's. 

Today, went to church, then off to my cousin, Alex's house, and went straight home. After some while, I went to our usual family prayer meetings at Priya's house, in Syosset, did the usual routine, ate some delicious food, and chit-chatted a bit. Overall, this was just another fantastic weekend. Well, anyway, it was fun while it lasted, now back to my studying for Java exam tomorrow.

posts.title: Amazing Weekend!
posts.markdown:
This past weekend, my dad and I went down to New Jersey to go visit family. At first, we went to my second cousin's child's birthday party and chit-chatted a bit with some of my cousins. Then, went off to go see other family members who lived in the area because my aunt (from India) wanted to visit them. That night, I stayed at my cousin, Anita's house, while my dad and aunt stayed with family in Jersey. 

Today, woke up (nice of waking up normally rather by waking up early for my church), and got ready to go to my cousin's church, St. Gregorios, Philadelphia. The church looked beautiful, except for the altars since it was still under construction. Also, I got to have the chance to participate and take Holy Qurbana from the new church. After service, while I ate lunch at church, I got to meet some family and friends. After church, went off to Anita's house for me to pack my stuff and then we three, me, dad, and aunty, rode off home to New York. Overall, I've had an amazing experience traveling here and there, and seeing some family and friends.

posts.title: The Weekend!
posts.markdown: It's been quite a long time since I wrote a blogpost. Anyway, this past weekend I attended St. John's MTC where they had their annual Night of Worship. The theme was "Be Still", based on Psalms 46, and the guest speaker was Mr. Shobi Varghese and his message was amazing. He discussed about some of his experiences, Mathew 6 & 7, and Deuteronomy 8\. After that, we had some snacks like cupcakes, cakes, chips, etc. and I met and talked to some friends from LIMC and St. John's MTC. Then, some cousins and I went to a local diner to eat for dinner and talked for a while, and I spent the night over at my cousin's house. On Sunday, I got up early exactly at 5AM (not usually an early bird), got ready for church, and my family picked me up from there to church. At church, it was English Holy Qurbana service, I received communion, and chit chatted with a few friends. Overall, it was another decent and blessed weekend!

posts.title: MGOCSM Back-to-School Retreat!
posts.markdown: Today, I went to St. Gregorios Church in Elmont, where we had our area back-to-school retreat. The guest speaker was the very own, Rev. Dn. Gregory Varghese, talking about preparing for the new academic year spiritually. One of the verses in which he referred to was St. Luke 12:48 and the temptations we go through everyday that distracts us from our way towards our goals. Greg semessan also mentioned the core values in our life, which are: family, work, and spiritual life. As well as, he discussed about the meaning of one of the qurbana's hymns, "_Blessed are those servants good..._", and how it all relates to our relationship with God. After that, we went into two small groups and discussed about different issues with school and church. Overall, it was an amazing and influential retreat.

posts.title: MGOCSM New York Leadership Camp 2008
posts.markdown:
This past Thursday (July 24th), I recently went to the MGOCSM Leadership Camp of 2008, which was hosted by the New York area, held in Ramapo College. The theme was _Uncovering Our Roots: Bringing Orthodoxy Back_. At first, it started off with me saying goodbye to my folks and headed off to LaGuardia Airport; Central Terminal at Baggage Claim. There, I was greeted by the NYLC Transportation Committee, and some new people still waiting for the bus. While still waiting, they played a few icebreaker games to keep us entertained. Anyway, I went on the van, to Ramapo, and on the way I met three people from Houston, one from Detroit, and the rest from my area. So, total in the van were eight (including myself), along with the driver, which happened to be Saju Chacko (aka MC Vikram). When we arrived there at Ramapo, I started to register at the NYLC front table and getting settled in my dorm room. After that, we started going off to dinner and evening prayers, and then there was the lighting of the lamp along with a few messages by Barnabas and Nicholovos Thiruminis, Mat semessan (General Secretary), and the co-conveners, Jomy Chandy and Anu Jacob. After all that, they showed some presentations (including the new AM-Team video), which is also shown on . We then were separated into our small groups, I was part of the A-Train. The first thing we had to do was an icebreaker, in which we had to do a small skit, without talking, and people had to guess what it was (my group was about the Paralytic). After the icebreaker, we had some refreshments and then went off to our area meetings to discuss about leadership. After the meeting, we had game night in the dorm lobby, in which everyone was playing either cards, pictionary, or even taboo. At the end of the night, we concluded by saying the compline prayers and heading off to bed. My roommates and I started staying up so late and talking about simple stuff. 

On Friday, I kind of woke up late, than the usual schedule. In the morning, we had a special wake-up call by the committee, banging drums and our doors to wake us up for prayers, devotional address by Gheevarghese chem, devotional songs, and our first main speaker, Fr. Josiah, who was funny in most of his speeches. Then, there were workshops discussing about the Church, noon prayer, lunch, and a small group activity, which was a scavenger hunt (my group came in second to last). Then, we had another main speaker, Mother Magdalena, refreshments, another small group discussion, panel discussion, and then dinner. After all that, we had evening prayer and devotional address by Daniel chem. Then, we got ready for a team building activity in the gym, including Blob tag. We all then went outside for a special ice cream treat, playing basketball and volleyball, talking, and music playing. This event was so memorable. It ended with compline prayers and we just sitting and talking to each other, including Daniel chem making fun of Tenny Thomas. 

On Saturday, it started off with the usual, this time I woke up nice and early. Some of us were tired during the lectures and workshops, but I tried keeping myself awake. All the small groups did something really cool, which was writing our own kukliyons. My group, however, did it small because we didn't have enough time to finish it. Anyway, we then had lunch, songs, and a presentation by the missions trip team of 2008\. We then went off to our area meetings to discuss about witnessing and the mission within our areas. After that, we had an MGOCSM General Assembly meeting discussing about the annual secretary and financial reports, along with electing a new Genral Secretary and Treasurer. After that, the 2009 Atlanta Leadership Camp committee shown us a promo presentation (also shown on YouTube). After that presentation, all the small groups presented our own kukliyons (my group had Jimmy Panicker from Chicago doing the censor), then the conveners presented the souvenirs, and then went off to dinner. After dinner, we had evening prayer, a retreat message, and meditational times before Sunday. 

On Sunday, we woke up at 5:30 AM, and then got ready for morning prayers and Holy Qurbana. After the service, we had our entire Leadership Camp group photo being taken, along with closing remarks by the conveners, a slide show, a reflection session by each area representative, and the lighting of the lamp for the 2009 leadership camp in Atlanta. After all that, we had lunch, packed our things, checked out, and said our goodbyes to each other. Overall, it was truly an amazing and blessed experience of my life, and I still miss everyone I met there. Here are some pictures I took at the camp. 
![](http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SJEqd-lwK6I/AAAAAAAAAKc/n5ZyeZrAkvw/s320/nylc08.jpg) 
![](http://4.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SI-PXtAs5yI/AAAAAAAAAJ8/P9WjiuM_MTk/s320/IMG_0246.JPG) 
![](http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SI-PgMyDgtI/AAAAAAAAAKE/evvuEiuSIXc/s320/IMG_0247.JPG) 
![](http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SI-PwxihLdI/AAAAAAAAAKM/7711Q8_vJSA/s320/IMG_0296.JPG) 
![](http://4.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SI-QPX4pCyI/AAAAAAAAAKU/Z-MLSuZCa34/s320/IMG_0398.JPG) 
Also, below is the official A-Train Kukliyon about St. Stephen, enjoy! 
[www.nylc08.com](http://www.nylc08.com)

posts.title: Adventure-Packed Weekend!
posts.markdown: Yesterday, on July 12, I went to Bushkill Falls, in the Poconos (also known as _The Niagara of Pennsylvania_), along with my cousins on a road trip. We were stuck in traffic for about thirty minutes, some cousins of mine blamed me because of my lateness. Anyway, when we got there, we first grabbed lunch, and I ate a chicken tenders meal, with fries and a Mountain Dew. After that, we went on our hiking trail and it was absolutely beautiful seeing nature and the falls flowing. It kind of made me reminisce about the time when I went on that trip to St. Tikhon's Seminary. So, anyway, most of us were a little tired about going up and down the stairs, of the mountain. After the hike, we then relaxed a bit, and then rode off home, back to New York. Also, we stopped at an outlet store on the way, Odd-A-Lot, in which one of my cousins bought fireworks to use for himself. So, we decided to grab some dinner at this Thai restaurant called _Jaiya_. Overall, it was a fun adventure and a great experience for me.

posts.title: Bible Study: Discipleship!
posts.markdown:
Today, I went to my MGOCSM Queens/Long Island/Brooklyn area bible study. We had our very own Rev.Dn.Daniel Mathai (aka Dennis) as our speaker. Today's bible study topic was about "_Discipleship_", talking about the lives of the Holy Apostles of Christ (including St. Paul), and the previous 13-day lent, which ended today. One of the key aspects of being a Disciple is _Faith_. Dn. Daniel pointed out two portions of the Bible which are Revelations 3:14-22 (explaining Lukewarm Christians) and the other, 1 Peter 3:8-22\. Anyway, I had fun being there and it was a great experience learning more about the disciples. 

<center>![](http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_81J2RsAe6x4/SiL4IszPJSI/AAAAAAAAATU/z0U83ahr54Q/s320/disciples.jpg)</center>

posts.title: Can we drink wine regularly?
posts.markdown: In my sunday school class discussion today, my teacher was asking us a question, "_Are we allowed to drink wine regularly?_" Well, as we went around sharing our answers, most of us said "_No, but there are certain conditions._" In my opinion, I was thinking about how we always drink the blood and body of our Lord every Sunday, so I guess it was okay. St. Paul writes in 1 Timothy 5:23 that, "_No longer drink only water, but use a little wine for your stomach's sake and your frequent infirmities._" Also, in the parable of the Good Samaritan, it says that he put wine on the beaten Jew's wounds, and then put olive oil. In other words, wine is good to heal wounds and for the body as a whole.

posts.title: Career Goals
posts.markdown:
Here is one of my essays (just the body paragraphs) that I wrote regarding my career goals in the future. Hope you all like it! 
_

> One of my career goals is to be in the information systems field. In the eighth grade, I became interested in this field and since then, I started looking at the e-mail exchanges and internet tools that my cousins were using for planning family events. So, I thought maybe we could start our own family discussion board or a family website. At first, I told one of my cousins about the project, but soon, it had quickly spread throughout the whole family. I started the project in 2005 and have maintained it ever since. Generally, this led to the desire in wanting to assist people in communicating through the technology that exists today and developing new ones for the future.

> Another career goal I would like to achieve would include being part of a top management firm that handles information systems or setting up an online sole proprietorship. Initially, I took many business classes at my local high school and received excellent grades. In these classes, I learned a variety of topics like web design, computer programming, software applications, and media production. A few of these classes were slightly difficult at first, however with hard work they became easy. Taking these business classes helped me build analytical and leadership skills. Therefore, pursuing majors like finance, business, or marketing will not only help me in developing my knowledge of the financial world and business models, but the classes within these majors will equip me with the proper communication, marketing, and strategic skills required to become a leader in the industry.

_

One of my career goals is to be in the information systems field. In the eighth grade, I became interested in this field and since then, I started looking at the e-mail exchanges and internet tools that my cousins were using for planning family events. So, I thought maybe we could start our own family discussion board or a family website. At first, I told one of my cousins about the project, but soon, it had quickly spread throughout the whole family. I started the project in 2005 and have maintained it ever since. Generally, this led to the desire in wanting to assist people in communicating through the technology that exists today and developing new ones for the future.
Another career goal I would like to achieve would include being part of a top management firm that handles information systems or setting up an online sole proprietorship. Initially, I took many business classes at my local high school and received excellent grades. In these classes, I learned a variety of topics like web design, computer programming, software applications, and media production. A few of these classes were slightly difficult at first, however with hard work they became easy. Taking these business classes helped me build analytical and leadership skills. Therefore, pursuing majors like finance, business, or marketing will not only help me in developing my knowledge of the financial world and business models, but the classes within these majors will equip me with the proper communication, marketing, and strategic skills required to become a leader in the industry.

Like, four people were changed by Christ on His way to Golgotha, Judas, Peter, Simon the Cyrene, and the good thief on the right side of Jesus. After that, I went straight to my cousin's house and stayed there for like two hours. On Sunday, I went to church, participated in the Holy Qurbana, and listened to another beautiful sermon by Dennis Mathai, about the story of the crippled woman.

posts.title: MGOCSM Trip
posts.markdown: I recently went on a trip, with the MGOCSM youth, to St. Tikhon's Orthodox Theological Seminary, which is located in South Canaan, Pennsylvania. We all toured around the Monastery, bookstore, the seminarians' dorms (Inside is the St. John Chrysostom Indian Orthodox Chapel), and even a walk in the woods. St. Tikhon's Seminary is very beautiful. For lunch, we had Subway sandwiches and after that, the seminarians showed us a slideshow presentation of photos, along with a tour of the St. Tikhon's chapel. We also got a pamphlet and an icon of our Lord Jesus Christ. We all had fun and it was a blessed event. Visit the [St. Tikhon's Indian Orthodox Blog](http://www.stotsindianorthodox.blogspot.com)
